attributes.comment:
I've reviewed the points regarding increase of immigration fee and service
improvements in USCIS. At present I am stationed in Tanzania participating in
the group processing of the Burundian 72 refugee group. When I'm not here I work
in refugee resettlement in Grand Rapids, MI with a small outreach service grant.
Daily I meet with low income refugees and asylees who have legal status in the
US who struggle to meet the fee requirements for applications as they are
presently set. These people are hard working and contribute through taxes. The
refugees were brought to the US with the understanding that they would have
rights and opportunities for their families. The financial strain of documents adds
additional stress to their adjustment--which presents itself in the care of thier
children, their performance in their work, and their overall life.

Being part of an organization currently inviting Burundian refugees to the US I
would hate to consider having to inform these people that they will never have the
opportunity to be a US citizen. With the so many of these families struggling after
resettlement, barely meeting poverty line incomes, such a significant portion of
thier income should not have to be used to gain rights. Law abiding, invited
refugees should not be held responsible for the inefficiency of USCIS processing,
nor should they be responsible to cover fees waived for others in equally difficult
situations. They pay their taxes, support their families, and are barely making it
with the current documentation expenses. We open our doors to assist these
people, not to charge them for their opportunities.

I hope those of you making these decisions will take the time to connect with your
local refugee service organizations to meet the people who will be effected so
significantly by this decision before voting. I can guarentee your decisions will be
swayed in their favor.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Holly R. Chadwick, Bethany Christian Services
